Dictionary.Name: The Collaborative International Dictionary of English v.0.44

Definition.WordDefinition:
Lean \Lean\ (l[=e]n), v. i. [imp. & p. p. {Leaned} (l[=e]nd), sometimes {Leant} (l[e^]nt); p. pr. & vb. n. {Leaning}.] [OE. lenen, AS. hlinian, hleonian, v. i.; akin to OS. hlin[=o]n, D. leunen, OHG. hlin[=e]n, lin[=e]n, G. lehnen, L. inclinare, Gr. kli`nein, L. clivus hill, slope. [root]40. Cf. {Declivity}, {Climax}, {Incline}, {Ladder}.] 1. To incline, deviate, or bend, from a vertical position; to be in a position thus inclining or deviating; as, she leaned out at the window; a leaning column. ``He leant forward.'' --Dickens. [1913 Webster]
2. To incline in opinion or desire; to conform in conduct; -- with to, toward, etc. [1913 Webster]
They delight rather to lean to their old customs. --Spenser. [1913 Webster]
3. To rest or rely, for support, comfort, and the like; -- with on, upon, or against. [1913 Webster]
He leaned not on his fathers but himself. --Tennyson. [1913 Webster]

Dictionary.Name: The Collaborative International Dictionary of English v.0.44

Definition.WordDefinition: Leaning \Lean"ing\, n. The act, or state, of inclining; inclination; tendency; as, a leaning towards Calvinism. [1913 Webster]

leaning adj 1: departing or being caused to depart from the true vertical or horizontal; "the leaning tower of Pisa"; "the headstones were tilted" [syn: {atilt}, {canted}, {tilted}, {tipped}] 2: resting against a support n 1: an inclination to do something; "he felt leanings toward frivolity" [syn: {propensity}, {tendency}] 2: a natural inclination; "he has a proclivity for exaggeration" [syn: {proclivity}, {propensity}] 3: the property possessed by a line or surface that departs from the vertical; "the tower had a pronounced tilt"; "the ship developed a list to starboard"; "he walked with a heavy inclination to the right" [syn: {tilt}, {list}, {inclination}, {lean}] 4: the act of deviating from a vertical position
